Review article
Strategies for fabricating versatile carbon nanomaterials from polymer precursors
Thanh-Hai Le b, Hyeonseok Yoon a, b, *
a School of Polymer Science and Engineering, Chonnam National University, 77 Yongbong-ro, Buk-gu, Gwangju 61186, South Korea b Department of Polymer Engineering, Graduate School, Chonnam National University, 77 Yongbong-ro, Buk-gu, Gwangju 61186, South Korea
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 3 May 2019 Received in revised form 10 June 2019 Accepted 12 June 2019 Available online 21 June 2019
Keywords: Polymer precursors Carbon Nanoparticles Nanostructures Carbonization Interface
* Corresponding author. School of Polymer Science E-mail address: hyoon@chonnam.ac.kr (H. Yoon).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.carbon.2019.06.053 0008-6223/© 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
There has been a continuous pursuit toward developing techniques used to prepare enhanced carbon nanomaterials over the last several decades. In particular, the demand for new and advanced carbon nanomaterials is related to the need to optimize their physicochemical characteristics for specific applications. In this regard, polymer precursors have great potential for fabricating nanostructured carbons with desirable properties since the chemical structure and surface/interface properties of the polymer can be designed and tailored during the preparation process. Various types of polymers including synthetic polymers, natural polymers, and biomass have been investigated as carbon precursors. Elaborate efforts have been made to prepare polymer nanoparticles, polymer blends, and nanocarbon/polymer hybrids for versatile carbon nanomaterials via heat treatment processes, for which knowledge and technologies regarding the interface and polymer chemistry/physics are required. In addition, more indepth studies into the carbonization mechanism may lead to various strategies for creating advanced carbon nanomaterials with desirable properties.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Facilities for manufacturing carbonmaterials have becomemore sophisticated in order to regulate key processing parameters in a controlled fashion. In addition, conventional reaction procedures have been refined to precisely tailor the structure and properties of carbon materials and, at the same time, new reaction strategies have been created. Advances in instrumental analysis, such as electron microscopy and scanning probe microscopy, have also allowed researchers to gain a better understanding of the structure and properties of carbon materials on both the nanometer and atomic scale. Scaling down the dimensions of interest when tailoring the structural characteristics of carbon has offered opportunities to achieve unprecedented, beneficial properties. A typical example includes the production of fullerenes from graphite using laser irradiation, which has lead researchers to change their attention to smaller dimensions, such as a few nanometer scales or less, namely the atomic scale [1]. Three-dimensional spherical fullerenes consisting of only several tens of carbon atoms exhibit unique physical and chemical properties, such as superconductivity and the photochromic effect. Furthermore, the discovery of fullerenes has aroused interest in new carbon allotropes with nanosized features, which has resulted in the synthesis of nanocarbon species such as carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and graphene. A huge amount of attention has been paid toward the synthesis and application of nanocarbon species over the past few decades. Research to fully exploit nanocarbon species is still active, for which continuous effort is being focused on the development of new or improved synthetic and post-synthetic techniques. For example, singlewalled CNTs (SWNTs), a representative class of one-dimensional sp2-hybridized carbon nanostructures, have been synthesized using electric arc discharge, laser ablation, and chemical vapor deposition (CVD) techniques. Arc discharge and laser ablation directly cause the sublimation of carbon from the graphite source at relatively high temperature, in which metals can be added as catalysts to the graphite source. In the case of the CVD process, gasphase carbon sources (usually hydrocarbon gas) flow through catalysts. Carbon atoms are vertically deposited on the catalyst particles to be shaped into tubular structures and thus, the major properties of the resulting nanotubes, such as their diameter and chirality, are mainly determined by the size and composition of the catalyst particles used. SWNTs have many fascinating properties, such as a wide range of conductivity (semiconducting to metallic), near-infrared fluorescence [2,3], and excellent mechanical strength, which depend on the diameter and chirality of the nanotubes. Well-known processes, such as HIPCO® and CoMoCAT®, have been developed to manufacture SWNTs. However, the diameters of the resulting SWNTs are small (<2 nm) and several different species of SWNTs exist within a narrow diameter range. However, there still remains plenty of room for improvement in the preparation of SWNTs. SWNTs can be prepared by rolling up two-dimensional sp2hybridized carbon single-layer graphene. Therefore, physicists have predicted potentially extraordinary properties of graphene, such as a charge carrier mobility of ~200,000 cm2 V 1 s 1 [4], thermal conductivity of ~5000Wm 1 K 1 [5], and Young's modulus of ~1100 GPa [6], which have captivated the interest of numerous researchers. Graphene is mostly produced using bottom-up CVD and top-down graphite exfoliation. In particular, due to the huge demand for next-generation electronics and optics, significant effort has been devoted to the production of large-area, highquality graphene using CVD on metal substrates. Laboratory scale strategies to prepare large-area CVD graphene have been reported with several successful experimental demonstrations for application in electronics, displays, and lighting [7,8]. However, the commercial application of graphene has not been realized to date,
which is probably because the aforementioned size, uniformity, and reliability problems have yet to be improved to satisfy industrial standards. The most problematic issue includes the lack of efficient methods for substrate transfer. During the substrate transfer process [9], the properties of CVD graphene may be degraded by residual impurities and undesirable chemical/microstructural defects. Strategies such as direct CVD onto the desired substrate [10] and roll-to-roll production [11] have been proposed to circumvent or improve these problems. A large number of research studies are still ongoing worldwide to put graphene into commercial use [12,13].
Everyone will have experienced that burning pieces of wood without much air results in charcoal, which is a typical example of producing carbonaceous materials from polymeric precursors. Although wood charcoal contains ash and other impurities due to the somewhat non-elaborate large-scale production process including oxygen, it was widely used as fuel before being replaced by coal. The first incandescent light bulb invented by Thomas Edison in 1879 employed carbon fiber filaments, which were prepared by baking cotton threads or bamboo slivers at high temperature. When heated, cotton and bamboo consisting of cellulose frameworks are converted into carbonaceous material. Today, carbon fibers are made mostly from petroleum-derived precursors, including polyacrylonitrile (PAN) and pitch, which have wide applications in other many industrial areas. Typically, PAN-based carbon fibers can exhibit beneficial properties, such as low weight, high stiffness/tensile strength, high chemical resistance, and high thermal stability, whichmakes them useful in composites, textiles, electrodes, and so forth. The diameter of carbon fibers usually ranges from a few to a few tens of micrometers to have high mechanical properties. However, the major properties of micrometer-sized fibers are determined by the microstructural characteristics of the fibers on a nanometer scale or even on a molecular scale. As a result, it is important to tailor the microstructures of bulk carbon and nanocarbon materials during their manufacturing process, for which an in-depth understanding of the structure-properties relationships in the nanometer regime is required.
Nowadays, various types of carbon material, including nanocarbon materials, have been produced via the pyrolysis of organic precursors, which have been utilized in many industrial areas such as filtration/separation, catalysis, electrochemistry, and composite engineering. Simply speaking, different precursors result in different carbon materials. Most starting materials used as carbon precursors are polymers. More than two polymer precursors can be used together and the original chemical structure of the precursor can be also modified. Therefore, multidisciplinary knowledge encompassing chemical synthesis/modification, polymer science, interface/surface science, and nanotechnology is essential to make progress in this research field. Herein, we introduce the strategies used to fabricate unique nanostructured carbon materials from polymer precursors. We address how polymer science can be coupled with interface science to create fascinating carbon nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 2. Carbonization mechanism
sections.text:
During the carbonization of organic precursors, non-carbon atoms such as hydrogen and nitrogen are removed, whereas the residual carbon atoms are assembled into sp-, sp2-, or sp3-hybridized carbon-based structures. In addition, heteroatoms and functional groups can also be introduced to the carbon-carbon bonds in many cases. Consequently, the quality of the resulting carbon materials is determined by what precursors were used and what processes they are subjected to, which limits their applications.
Therefore, it is important to understand the carbonization mechanism depending on the type of precursor used and the process variables. However, in order to transform the precursors into carbon materials, diverse multistage reactions proceed rapidly at high temperatures under an inert atmosphere. Therefore, it is not an easy task to investigate the reaction mechanism of precursors for carbonization.

sections.heading: 2.1. Typical polymeric carbon precursors, PAN
sections.text:
Three main precursors used for the production of carbon fibers include PAN, rayon, and pitch. Presently, the majority of carbon fibers are made from PAN-based precursors. In terms of their chemical structures, cyclic and aromatic ring structures are advantageous for being converted into carbon materials with high char yields. The linear polymer PAN can also be transformed into a ladder-type naphthyridine structure at ~200e300 C under an air atmosphere, namely in the presence of oxygen, making it the best carbon precursor available to date. The graphitization mechanism of PAN has been investigated using various analytical tools bymany research groups. Nevertheless, the chemistry of the stabilization of PAN remains not completely established. The most widely accepted mechanism is presented in Fig. 1. Cyclization of the nitrile side chains in PAN result in chemically unstable aliphatic ring sequences during the first stage and subsequent dehydration in the presence
of oxygen leads to the formation of more stable polyaromatics (Path 1). Further oxidation can occur, which makes polyaromatics bearing oxygen-containing functional groups. In fact, the incorporation of oxygen groups is undesirable because they reduce the char yield in the final stage. However, oxygen is essential for the dehydration step (resulting in condensation) leading to aromatization. When oxygen inhibits the cyclization reaction as a radical scavenger, oxygen dehydrates the aliphatic CeC chains, at least partially, before cyclization and further dehydrogenation and cyclization reactions proceed simultaneously (Path 2).
To sum up, the mechanistic pathways during the stabilization process may involve the following three reaction steps:
1. Cyclization of the nitrile side chains, leading to ladder-like structures, 2. Formation of conjugated sp2-hybridized systems via oxygeninduced dehydrogenation reactions along the polymer backbone or the ladder-like structure, and 3. Further oxidation of the resulting polyaromatics, resulting in the generation of hydroxyl and carbonyl functionalities.
These in-depth insights into the mechanism make it possible to offer efficient solutions for several problematic issues preventing the wider industrial application of PAN-based carbon materials. First, although the unique low-temperature thermal stabilization process enables linear polymer PAN to be converted into carbon materials, it requires much time and energy. Thus, great effort has been made to reduce the production cost of PAN-based carbon materials by improving the stabilization process, whilst maintaining their desirable properties. On the basis of the mechanism shown in Fig. 1, polar functionalities such as C¼O, OH, and COOH can be introduced into the polymer chains to facilitate the initiation of the cyclization process through nucleophilic attack and accelerating the subsequent oxidative ring closure reactions. Consequently, the processing time and energy for the stabilization are reduced, enabling large savings in the manufacturing cost. In addition, due to the difficulties in PAN processing (e.g., melt processing: thermal degradation; solution processing: low solubility), PAN copolymers rather than homopolymers are widely used. Typically, acidic co-monomers such as acrylic acid, methacrylic acid, and itaconic acid are favored for the production of commercial PAN-based carbon materials. Post-polymerization/processing modifications can be used to indirectly affect the stabilization process [16]. For example, coating agents such as silicone-based resins and long-chain fatty acid derivatives can be coated onto the PAN surface and used to suppress the exotherm during the cyclization reaction. In addition, Lewis acids, organic bases, and inorganic compounds can be used to catalyze the cyclization reaction. As a result, it is important to investigate the carbonization mechanism of organic precursors because it offers some ways toward improving the process for carbonization and to tailor the properties of the resulting products.

sections.heading: 2.2. Nanocarbon coalescence
sections.text:
From a different point of view, another interesting example regarding the formation mechanism of carbon materials on the nanometer scale includes the production of double-walled carbon nanotubes (DWNTs) from fullerene-filled SWNTs, which are known as “peapods” [19e24]. Thermal energy under an inert atmosphere induces the coalescence of the fullerenes, where the constituent carbon atoms in fullerenes are rearranged to a concentric cylinder wall of graphene inside the SWNTs. In other words, fullerenes, which are spherical sp2-hybridized carbon nanostructures, can be transformed using thermal energy into smaller-diameter carbon
nanotubes (0.4e0.7 nm in diameter) without any additional catalysts in the confined interior of the SWNTs. The graphitic sp2-hybridized bond is highly stable. However, fullerenes in SWNTs have been observed to coalesce at ~1100 C [25,26], which is significantly lower than the decomposition temperature of fullerenes (>4000 C) [27]. Thus, great effort has been made to examine the mechanism of the fullerene coalescence and the transformation of the sp2-hybridized carbon networks [17]. It has been found that the 90 rotation of a CeC bond in a sp2-hybridized carbon network, the Stone-Wales transformation, allows the rearrangement of the carbon atoms to become possible [17,18]. The Stone-Wales transformation, a reversible diatomic interchange (Fig. 2), is characterized by the lowest activation energy barrier when compared with other possible atomic rearrangements. DWNTs can also be obtained using ferrocene-filled SWNTs as the precursor [28]. In this case, the growth temperature of the inner tubes was much lower when compared with the peapod method. The inner tubes start to grow at temperatures as low as 600 C, indicating that the formation mechanism of the inner tube resembles the growth of SWNTs via a CVD process using ferrocene as a catalyst, which is in contrast with the catalyst-free peapod method [29]. It is important to note that an in-depth study on the growthmechanism of the inner tube in DWNTs will provide opportunities to control the chiral angle and diameter of the inner tube, which may be extended to other carbon nanomaterials. Minute structural controls on amolecular level can ultimately lead to enormous changes in the properties of the bulk carbon material. However, due to the harsh CeC bond transformation conditions, relatively little research has been carried out in this area to date. Integrating nanocarbon species into polymers to prepare unique carbon precursors is discussed later in Section 3.3. A better understanding of the fundamental mechanism will provide insight into what phenomenon occurs at the interface between the nanocarbon materials and polymer precursor, making it possible to design unique precursors and predict their characteristics.

sections.heading: 3. Polymer precursors
sections.text:
Strategies regarding what and how polymer precursors can be utilized to achieve versatile carbon nanomaterials will be addressed in this section with an emphasis on the interfacial aspects: i) Polymer nanoparticles, ii) polymer blends, and iii) nanocarbon/polymer ensembles. By using various nanotechnologies regarding interfaces, well-defined polymer nanoparticles can be prepared, sometimes with modified chemical functionalities, of which several can be converted into their carbon counterparts via heat treatment. The resulting carbonmaterials can inherit their size and morphology from the polymer nanoparticle precursors. A number of polymers exist and furthermore their chemical
structures can be modified. Thus, blending qualitatively different polymers offers innumerable options to explore possibilities to obtain carbon precursors with desirable characteristics. Lastly, when polymer precursors are coupled with nanocarbon species, many synergistic effects can be anticipated by taking advantage of the chemical/physical phenomena arising from the carbon/polymer interface.

sections.heading: 3.1. Polymer nanoparticles
sections.text:
Many polymer nanoparticles have been investigated for use as carbon precursors. The great advantages of using well-made polymer nanoparticles include facile control over the size and morphology of the resulting carbon nanoparticles. The manufacture of carbon black (usually a few tens of nanometers in diameter) for industrial applications has been achieved using the incomplete combustion or thermal decomposition of hydrocarbons. However, it is not easy to control the particle size distribution, morphology, and interparticle aggregation. More elaborate CVD techniques allowing the production of CNTs with diameters of a few nanometers also suffer from undesirable by-products, such as amorphous carbons and catalyst residues, making the as-obtained products undergo an additional sophisticated separation process for practical use. On the other hand, provided that appropriate polymer precursors can bemade into nanoparticles with controlled size and shape, they can simply be converted into carbon nanoparticles via heat treatment. However, the problem is that it is not easy to prepare well-defined polymer nanoparticles when compared to inorganic nanoparticles. Polymers consist of repeating units linked by covalent bonds in chains, where the covalent bonds are directional, which is in contrast to metallic and ionic bonds. The inherent characteristics of polymers make them unstable when shaped into nanoparticles. In particular, the dimensional stability of polymers abruptly decreases in the nanometer scale, which is a major obstacle to preparing well-defined polymer nanoparticles. It should also be noted that the heat treatment conditions used for the carbonization of polymer nanoparticles are very different from that of their bulk counterparts. In the case of these nanoparticles, during the heat treatment process used for carbonization, relatively limited carbon materials are provided from the nanometer-sized precursors when compared to their bulk counterparts. Therefore, these intermediate structures are easily degraded during the carbonization process, which may result in unfavorably low char yields. In addition, due to the formation of more compact and dense structures toward graphitization, a notable size reduction commonly occurs in the resulting nanocarbon products. As a result, substantial effort should be paid toward seeking heat treatment conditions specifically optimized for nanoparticle precursors.
Strategies achieving the enhanced dimensional stability of polymers on a nanometer scale may include strengthening the inter-/intra-chain interactions and cross-linking polymer chains. As a notable example, conducting polymers have strong interchain interactions due to their unique p-conjugated systems, whichmake them more advantageous for preserving the dimensional stability in the nanometer region. Most conducting polymers are insoluble in common solvents, which can be attributed to the strong intermolecular interactions in the polymers. p-electron conjugation can be made easily from aromatic repeating units, which are favorable to undergo carbonization (transforming into graphitic structures). Therefore, conducting polymers with aromatic rings as repeating units such as polypyrrole (PPy) and polyaniline (PANI) have been frequently converted into carbon materials via heat treatment. Moreover, conducting polymers mostly include heteroatoms in their molecular structures, such as nitrogen and sulfur, which allows the introduction of heteroatoms into the carbon matrix. The
crystallinity of the carbon matrix diminishes in the presence of heteroatoms. However, heteroatoms can act as dopants, affecting the chemical properties of the carbon matrix as well as its electronic properties, which may endow the resulting carbon materials with attractive characteristics for new applications. A recent review by Inagaki et al. addressed the effect of nitrogen doping on the major properties of carbon materials [30].
PPy, which is one of the most prominent conducting polymers reported to date, has the repeating unit of a five-membered aromatic ring containing a nitrogen heteroatom. Together with the strong inter-/intra-chain interactions formed by p-electron conjugation, PPy chains can be cross-linked during polymerization. Fig. 3 describes the growth of PPy chains during oxidative polymerization. In the pyrrole-pyrrole coupling reaction, protons in the a site of the ring are more readily eliminated than those in the b site via oxidation. Therefore, aea linkages are preferred when the monomers are coupled to each other, which results in a linear PPy chain. A high degree of aea coupling between the pyrrole monomers renders a high degree ofp-electron conjugation. On the other hand, aeb coupling can also occur, especially under stronger oxidative conditions, which induces branching or cross-linking of the polymer chains. The aeb linkage reduces the linearity and planarity of PPy chains, which may degrade the charge transport properties of the polymer. However, it is effective for improving the dimensional stability of the polymer in the nanometer region. Consequently, spherical PPy nanoparticles have been prepared as a carbon precursor in the presence of surfactant [32,33]. The formation of micelles with uniform size as a type of nanoreactor is very important to the production of nanoparticles, for which destabilization mechanisms such as Ostwald ripening should be suppressed during the polymerization process. Alcohols or alkanes with C4 to C12 chain lengths, highly depending on the type of surfactant used, can be used as a co-surfactant to strengthen the micelle nanoreactor. A completely different and interesting approach to obtain PPy nanospheres has also been reported [34], in which a metal-cation/ polymer-stabilizer complex was used, not a molecular surfactant. Usually, water-soluble polymer stabilizers are employed in dispersion or suspension polymerization, yielding micron-sized particles. However, in this approach, the iron cations acting as the initiator are bound to the polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) stabilizer, making it possible to produce nanometer-sized PPy particles by effectively suppressing the particle growth under enhanced steric stabilization. As a result, spherical PPy nanoparticles with diameters of 20e60 nm were prepared without using any surfactants and specific templates, offering great potential for the mass production of polymer nanoparticles. Unfortunately, polymeric stabilizers, which may be adsorbed on the particle surface, leave the carbonaceous
residues after the heat treatment process, while the molecular surfactants are readily decomposed at high temperature.
A notable example includes the fabrication of magnetic carbon nanospheres from PPy nanosphere precursors using a surfactant templating approach (Fig. 4). First, spherical PPy nanoparticles were prepared in an emulsion system employing dodecyltrimethylammonium bromide (DTAB) and decyl alcohol as the surfactant and co-surfactant, respectively. Chemical polymerization of pyrrole monomers proceeded using iron(III) chloride as an oxidizing agent in the emulsion system, resulting in monodisperse spherical nanoparticles with an average diameter of 60 nm (Fig. 4a). The well-defined PPy nanoparticles were converted into carbon nanoparticles via heat treatment at 850 C under an inert atmosphere. Changes in the molecular structure of PPy during the heat treatment process were investigated by the Ito group using Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, electron spin resonance spectroscopy, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA), and conductivity measurements [35]. The electrical conductivity of conducting polymer PPy precursors has allowed researchers to gain insight into the carbonization mechanism by correlating the conductivity with the molecular structure. The conductivity of PPy doped with ClO4 dropped from 200 to 300 C, which then increased gradually upon heating to 500 C. Above 500 C, the conductivity increases rapidly and becomes higher than that of the original PPy precursor at 750 C. However, it is notable that the conductivity transition temperature strongly depends on the doping status of PPy. Instrumental analyses including elemental analysis indicate that the decomposition of PPy accompanied by the loss of the dopant ion (ClO4 ) in the temperature range of 150e300 C was responsible for the initial drop in the conductivity. The subsequent loss of nitrogen atoms occurs between 400 and 600 C, which was also correlated with the increase in conductivity observed in this temperature range. In other words, at this stage, polycondensed aromatic hydrocarbons start to form, leading to an increase in the conductivity. Importantly, as described in Fig. 4b, iron species were doped in the PPy chains during the polymerization process, which were then converted to a-Fe and g-Fe2O3 under the heat treatment conditions used for the carbonization step. The introduction of these magnetic phases into the carbon matrix gives the carbon nanoparticles ferromagnetic characteristics. As seen in Fig. 4c, the magnetic carbon nanoparticles (MCNPs) are well preserved in the morphology of the polymer precursor, with the exception that the diameter decreased by 20%. Since heat energy initially stimulates the exterior of the polymer precursor during the heat treatment process, the formation of compact structures toward graphitization proceeds from the surface of the precursor to the center, resulting in the size reduction. Similar to other polymer precursors, the carbonized PPy nanoparticles (MCNPs) were microporous. Remarkably, the micropore volume of the MCNPs was as high as 0.15 cm3 g 1, which is comparable to that of ZSM-5, a typical zeolite. The advantages of PPy as a carbon precursor include that the nitrogen atoms in the pyrrole repeating unit can be left in the carbon matrix under appropriate heat treatment conditions. While the atomic size of nitrogen or boron is similar to that of carbon, their characteristics are different. Therefore, considerable attention has been paid to the doping of these atoms into nanocarbon species [36e39]. Although the doped atoms are defects from a microstructural point of view, they can provide new electronic, optical, thermal, and chemical properties to the nanocarbon species. Finally, it is important to note that the uniform size and morphology of nitrogen-doped MCNPs have allowed their application in catalysis, energy conversion, drug delivery, removal of dyes, and sensing [40e46].
As a typical example, palladium nanoclusters were deposited onto the MCNPs for use as a heterogeneous catalyst in various
coupling reactions [41]. The palladium precursor was impregnated into the MCNPs with a nitrogen content of 4e5wt% in the aqueous phase. The nitrogen sites in the MCNPs may have a strong interaction with palladium cations, facilitating the wetting of the palladium precursor onto the MCNP support without the need for any additional functionalization process. Moreover, the microporous surface of the MCNPs offers steric restriction to confine the precursor and furthermore, prevent the growth of the palladium nanoclusters. As seen in Fig. 5a, despite a high loading amount (40wt%), palladium nanoparticles with an average diameter of 3.8 nm were well dispersed onto the MCNPs via reduction using hydrogen. The particle size distribution of the palladium nanoparticles was also reasonably narrow. It is very important to retrieve heterogeneous catalysts after catalytic reactions to prevent contamination of the target product. The magnetic property of the MCNPs, as displayed in Fig. 5b, enabled the efficient recovery and recycling of the catalytic nanoparticles from the reaction solution, upon applying an external magnetic field. As a result, the palladium nanocluster-deposited MCNPs showed high conversion and yields for different types of coupling reactions including the Heck, Suzuki, and Sonogashira reactions, and could be reused several times without any significant loss in their catalytic activity (Fig. 5c). The uniform size of the MCNP support may facilitate the diffusion of reactants and the strong anchoring of highly dispersed palladium nanoclusters on the MCNPs contribute to the remarkable catalytic performance.
PPy nanotubes, a different nanostructure, have also been prepared via a cylindrical micelle templating process in a water-in-oil
phase [47]. An anionic surfactant, sodium bis(2-ethylhexyl)sulfosuccinate (AOT) formed reverse cylindrical micelles with the aid of iron(III) chloride, where the anionic headgroups of AOT were capped with iron cations. When pyrrole monomers were added to the reverse cylindrical micellar phase, they were polymerized by the iron cations along the micelle template. Consequently, PPy nanotubes with diameters of 93± 15 nm and lengths of 8± 4 mm were fabricated and residual iron species were trapped within the nanotubes even after an appropriate washing process. The ironimpregnated PPy nanotubes were successfully converted into carbon nanotubes showing ferromagnetic behavior via heat treatment at 800 C. Due to the low oxidation potential (0.8 V) of the pyrrole monomer, the chemical oxidative polymerization of pyrrole can readily proceed with various metal cations, such as silver(I) [48] and copper(II), which shows great potential for preparing versatile metal/carbon nanocomposites via heat treatment. Another interesting work by the Che group demonstrated the production of enantiopure chiral CNTs (CCNTs) using double-helical PPy nanotubes as the carbon precursor. L- and D-Glutamic acid surfactants were used as templates for the formation of left- and right-handed chiral PPy nanotubes as a result of electrostatic interactions formed between the surfactant and monomer [49]. After carbonization at 550e950 C, chiral PPy nanotubes were converted to enantiopure chiral CCNTs with well-maintained helical morphology, a large specific area of ~130m2 g 1, and pore size of 25 nm. Furthermore, they exhibited higher charge storage performance in lithium-ion batteries when compared with conventional CNTs.
Similarly, a polymer nanofiber precursor can be used to develop
carbon nanofibers. Zhang et al. [50] prepared PPy nanofibers via polymerization of pyrrole monomers inside mesoporous silica channels, which act as a sacrificial template. The outer silica shell of the template channel functions as a barrier to prevent the agglomeration of the high-aspect-ratio precursors during the carbonization at high temperatures, successfully leading to the formation of uniform and ultrathin carbon nanofibers with diameters <1 nm. While the use of a hard template allows the fabrication of finely structured nanosized polymer precursors, it has serious drawbacks such as complicated synthetic processes, high cost, and limited scale-up for large-scale production. As an alternative to the hard template approach, soft templates can be used, which mainly consist of surfactants. For example, the Huang group demonstrated that a cationic surfactant, cetyltrimethylammonium bromide, can be used as a template to generate PPy nanofiber webs, which were successfully converted to carbon nanofiber webs [51].
Electrospinning is a useful technique used to produce polymer fiber precursors in large quantities, at least on a laboratory scale. Poly(ionic liquid)s (PILs), a class of polyelectrolytes with melting points less than 100 C, have been successfully electrospun to produce continuous nanofibers as carbon precursors [52]. The carbonization of two PIL nanofibers consisting of poly(3-allyl-1-
vinyl imidazolium dicyanamide) and poly(1-allyl-4-vinyl pyridinium dicyanamide), respectively, resulted in 6.3% and 8.0% nitrogen-doped carbon nanofibers, which exhibit high electrical conductivities up to 200 S cm 1.
In general, electrospun nanofibers are obtained in the form of a network or web. Therefore, electrospun nanofibers tend to be fused together due to conglutination or melting during the heat treatment process. The Tang group [53] reported the catalytic carbonization of chlorinated poly(vinyl chloride) (CPVC) microfibers (Fig. 6). Irregular-shaped amorphous carbon was obtained without using any catalysts during heat treatment process as a result of the destructive melting of CPVC prior to carbonization. However, welldefined, uniform carbon microfibers were obtained after the carbonization of the CPVC microfibers in the presence of a Fe3O4 catalyst. Since FeCl3 originating from the Fe3O4 catalyst is a strong Lewis acid, it not only catalyzed the dehydrochlorination of CPVC into polyene, but also the subsequent cross-linking of the resulting polyene to form char. Although this is a specific example to circumvent undesirable interparticle aggregation during the heat treatment process, it provides good insight into how polymers can be chemically modified to become appropriate carbon precursors.
Sacrificial organic and inorganic nanoparticles such as polystyrene and silica can be incorporated into polymers as porogens,
and used to fabricate hollow carbon nanoparticles [54e56]. Recently, a silica/polydopamine core-shell nanocomposite was prepared by mixing dopamine and silica nanospheres in 0.01M Tris-buffer (pH 8.5) [57]. Dopamine has both amine and catechol functional groups in its structure and thus, it undergoes spontaneous self-polymerization and deposition on the surface of the silica nanospheres to form the core-shell nanocomposite. Interestingly, the thickness of the polydopamine coating can be precisely controlled at a high resolution of 1 nm. After heating at 800 C under a nitrogen atmosphere, the polydopamine was converted into carbon with a char yield of 60%, and hollow carbon nanospheres were obtained by etching the silica in hydrofluoric acid. Moreover, incorporation of metal nanoparticles into the silica precursor led to a unique structure, metal/carbon yolk-shell nanocomposites. The inner/outer diameters and textural properties of the hollow carbon nanoparticles can be conveniently tailored by controlling what and how the polymer precursors and porogens are combined [58].
Without employing any sacrificial porogens, it is also possible to directly fabricate hollow polymer nanoparticles using micelle
templates with appropriate monomers. As an example, the polymerization of a mixture of aniline and pyrrole monomers in the presence of Triton X-100 generates PANI-co-PPy hollow nanospheres [59]. Triton X-100 spherical micelles were swollen by the co-monomers and then act as the template for the generation of the hollow structure, in which the key variables determining the size and uniformity of the hollow nanospheres were the concentration of the surfactant and co-monomers, and the pyrrole-to-aniline molar ratio. The conjugated structure of the PANI-co-PPy precursor ensures sufficient carbonization of the framework with an inherited nanostructure. The copolymer hollow nanosphere precursors are converted to hollow carbon nanospheres with a large surface area of up to 3022m2 g 1 using a simple carbonization process [60,61].
It is also noteworthy that covalent-organic frameworks (COFs) have been designed as a precursor to produce carbon nanomaterials with tailored porosity and doped heteroatoms. COFs are a class of porous and crystalline polymers, which contain non-carbon elements such as boron, nitrogen, oxygen, and sulfur. COFs consist of small p-conjugatedmolecular building blocks that are connected
by covalent bonds, which exhibit excellent dimensional stability in the nanometer scale. Moreover, the pore size and structure of COFs are tunable upon changing the building blocks with various functional groups and the synthetic methods. Due to these fascinating characteristics, COF-based nanoparticles have been prepared and converted into functional carbon nanomaterials for various applications [62e64]. Likewise, over two decades, remarkable progress has been made in the development of polymer nanoparticle precursors used for the preparation of carbon nanomaterials with designed properties and structures. Different preparation methodologies, polymer precursors and nanostructures, and heat treatment conditions have been investigated, as summarized in Table 1.

sections.heading: 3.2. Polymer blends
sections.text:
The use of polymers as carbon precursors can take advantage of various polymer science phenomena to fabricate unique nanostructured carbons. The most well-known example includes the microphase separation of different polymers. Blending more than two polymers, where all of them can be carbon precursors or some of them just degradable polymers, results in phase separation, which significantly affects the morphology and properties of the resulting carbonized products. The simplest example showing the effect of blending polymers is the fabrication of hollow nanofibers via electrospinning without using a co-axial nozzle. As introduced earlier, electrospinning has been widely used because it allows the facile production of well-defined polymer fibers with diameters ranging from the submicron to nanometer scale. Under a high applied voltage, the polymer solution or melt is ejected from a nozzle spinneret, yielding fibers. Using a coaxial spinneret allows two solutions or melts to be fed simultaneously, which are spun into nanofibers in a coaxial configuration, and a subsequent core solvent-etching or thermal-degradation step results in hollow nanofibers. Even though the coaxial spinneret nozzle is used for coelectrospinning, it is quite hard to achieve good concentricity in the core and shell components along the fiber axis. On the other hand, coaxial nanofibers consisting of two different immiscible polymers can also be electrospun from a single spinneret nozzle when the polymer blend exhibits appropriate phase separation behavior. Blending PAN with poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) in dimethylformamide (DMF) is the most popular combination used to obtain electrospun coaxial nanofibers from a single spinneret nozzle. Yarin et al. also demonstrated a single-spinneret co-electrospinning technique using blends of PMMA/PAN solutions in DMF [71]. They found that spherical PMMA droplets are dispersed in the PAN continuous phase (Fig. 7a) and, under an applied electric force, the outer PAN flow pulls the inner PMMA droplets from the tip into
the Taylor cone, successfully generating a continuous PMMA-PAN core-shell jet (Fig. 7b). The PMMA phase can be solvent-etched or thermally pyrolyzed, resulting in carbon fibers with a hollow interior. Specifically, instead of using sophisticated accessories such as a coaxial spinneret nozzle, a judicious combination of different polymers makes it easy to produce hollow fibers for use as carbon
their applications.
precursors. Furthermore, this approach can be extended to creating multichannel porous carbon fibers via co-electrospinning a blend of PAN and a block copolymer, poly(acrylonitrile-co-methyl methacrylate) [72]. The typical carbon precursor PAN has been combined with PMMA to produce unique carbon nanostructures [73e75].
Similar to the PAN/PMMA pair, the so-called “blending the matrix/labile polymers” concept can be applied to the fabrication of various carbon structures. Yang and Inagaki recently reviewed the blending techniques of polymers used as carbon precursors, focusing on the combination of a matrix polymer with a labile polymer [76]. The matrix forming polymers encompass PAN, polyimides, phenolic resins, poly(phenyl oxide) and pitches while the labile polymers include poly(N-vinyl-2-pyrrolidone) (PVP), polystyrene, polyethylene, poly(ethylene glycol), polyurethane, and polybenzimidazole. Different carbon structures including porous materials, porous nanofibers, and hollow nanofibers can be prepared using an appropriate combination of the carbon precursor polymer with a sacrificial, degradable polymer. Hulicova and Oya reported a polymer blending strategy used to fabricate three different carbon structures, porous carbon fibers, thin carbon fibers, and CNTs [77]. Novolac-type phenol-formaldehyde (PF) resin and maleinic acid-modified polyethylene were employed as the carbon precursor and heat-labile polymer, respectively, which were used to produce fibers with aligned long pores. Thin carbon fibers were prepared using the PF precursor and high-density polyethylene as a heat-labile polymer. Similarly, PMMA was employed as a heatlabile polymer with the PAN carbon precursor to obtain CNTs. PMMA/PAN/PMMA three-layered core-shell microparticles with diameters of ~500 nm were prepared. Subsequent melt-spinning followed by heat treatment resulted in CNTs with diameters of 10e20 nm. The above examples represent the importance of phase separation in polymer blends when designing and fabricating various carbon structures. The effect of the phase separation is amplified when the dimensions of interest become smaller and reach the nanometer scale. Further specific examples are given below.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Effective porosity development
sections.text:
It is easy to estimate and understand the phase behavior of binary polymer blends. Although blending more than two polymers gives rise to more complex phase behavior, it provides more opportunities to create unique, fascinating polymer-based carbon precursors. A recent work has demonstrated the development of effective porosity in carbon nanofibers exploiting the phase behavior of ternary polymer blends used as the precursor [78]. Ternary blends consisting of PAN, PMMA, and PVP showed phase separation behavior dependent on the intermolecular interactions between each pair of the blended polymers. Specifically, while PMMA is thermodynamically incompatible with PAN, PVP is miscible with either PAN or PMMA. Therefore, PVP may play a role in reducing the interfacial tension between PAN and PMMA. The phase behavior of the ternary blend depends on the weight ratio of the component polymers in a solvent such as DMF. Thus, the blends were prepared at various compositions, as shown in Fig. 8a, and their phase separation behavior was then examined using optical microscopy (Fig. 8b). As expected, no segregated domains were observed in the PMMA/PVP binary blend at an optical microscopic level. On the other hand, spherical domains were found in the ternary blends, where the size of the domains gradually decreased at higher PVP concentrations (d, h, and n in Fig. 8b). This supports that PVP reduces the interfacial tension between PAN and PMMA. Fig. 8c shows the morphology of the carbonized products prepared via heat treatment of the electrospun polymer nanofibers formed using the compositions given in Fig. 8a. Considering the microstructures of the electrospun polymer nanofibers before and after
the carbonization process, the following hypotheses can be reasonably suggested: (i) In the PAN/PMMA (dispersed phase/ continuous phase) blend, due to the high interfacial tension, each phase can be coaxially oriented during the electrospinning process, ultimately leading to the unique bundle-like structures shown in carbonized products d and h; (ii) in the presence of PVP, due to the reduced interfacial tension between PAN and PMMA, the degree of phase segregation in the fiber tends to decrease with increasing PVP (see products d, h, and p). Further insight into the phase behavior of the ternary polymer blend can be gained from the intermolecular interaction between each pair of the blended polymers. Fig. 8d presents the calculated interaction energy of the blended polymer pairs as a function of the separation distance. It is remarkable that the PAN/PMMA pair shows completely different curves when compared to those of the PAN/PVP and PMMA/PVP pairs. The minimum interaction energy (Eminint ) was found to be the highest for the PAN/PMMA pair, indicating that the PAN/PMMA pair is the most thermodynamically unstable. It was calculated that the PAN/PMMA pair has no intermolecular interactions. However, PVP can form hydrogen bonds with PAN and PMMA, where the strength of the hydrogen bonds was in the order of PMMA/PVP< PAN/PVP. The different intermolecular interactions observed among the polymer pairs cause different phase behaviors in the PAN/PMMA/ PVP ternary blends and the qualitative characteristics of the polymers as carbon precursors are completely different. The carbonization of PAN usually yields microporous carbon with ineffective/ isolated porosities, while PMMA acts as a porogen in the carbonized products. PVP is transformed into solid and smooth carbonmaterial with low char yield. However, blending PAN and/or PMMA with PVP at appropriate compositions form carbonized products with open and effective porosity (product g). Ultimately, these points lead to the composition-dependent microstructures of the postcarbonization products (see the textural properties shown in Fig. 8e). It is also important to note that the effective porosity was demonstrated via a comparative experiment using small-molecule sulfuric acid and the large-molecule ionic liquid [HMIM][PF6] as electrolytes. The carbonized products with effective porosity showed better electrochemical activity although the specific surface areas were smaller.
As stated in earlier, electrospinning PAN/PMMA blends is the most popular approach to yield porous carbon fibers (PCFs). However, control over the porosity of the PCFs still remains challenging because the macrophase separation of the blended polymers frequently leads to poor pore structures after carbonization. As a notable example, employing PAN and PMMA in a form of block copolymer PAN-b-PMMA is favorable for the fabrication of uniform and hierarchical porous carbon nanostructures [79]. The block copolymer shows a microphase separation in the fibers, namely uniform PMMA nanodomains as a dispersed phase in the PAN matrix. After oxidation at 280 C followed by pyrolysis at 800 C, the block copolymer fibers were converted to carbon fibers with well-controlled and uniformly distributed pores throughout the fiber body (Fig. 9). The as-prepared PCFs exhibited hierarchically interconnected meso- and micropores with a high surface area of 503m2 g 1 and rich nitrogen content of 12.8%. Moreover, the PCFs were further decorated with MnO2 to achieve enhanced electron/ ion transport properties [80]. This kind of approach can be extended to other two-dimensional carbon nanomaterials such as porous thin films. Zhou et al. [81] described the effect of the solvent and thermal oxidation on the preparation of mesoporous carbon thin films from PAN-b-PMMA precursors. The block copolymer was microphase-separated into uniformly spaced globular nanostructures on a siliconwafer, where the spacing between center-tocenter and the pore size was susceptible to thermal and solvent annealing. Thermal oxidation at temperatures ranging from 100 to
300 Cwas performed to convert the PAN phase into a stable ladder structure. Subsequent heat treatment at 800 C resulted in a mesoporous carbon thin film via pyrolysis of the PMMA phase.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Metal decoration
sections.text:
Various polymers have the capability to coordinate with metal cations, offering opportunities to readily incorporate a metal phase in a controlled fashion to the resulting carbon via heat treatment. Metal-coordinated polymers exhibit different phase behavior and the metal precursors are thermally reduced to metal atoms during the heat treatment step used for carbonization. Metal-coordinated polymers can be blended with other polymers, offering opportunities to control the incorporation of the metal phase into the carbonized products. As an interesting example, a unique threedimensional nanohybrid architecture has been fabricated with manganese oxide (MnO)-decorated CNFs [82]. To simply obtain the
MnO/CNFs, PAN, PVP, and manganese(II) acetate were first dissolved in DMF. The solubility parameters of the three constituents, PVP, PAN, and DMF, are similar at 25.6, 25.3e26.1, and 24.8 MPa1/2, which means theoretically they are miscible. PVP has a pendant lactam group in its repeating unit, which can coordinate with manganese cations, as described in Fig. 10a. Optical microscopy showed the addition of the manganese precursor into the PAN/PVP blend induces phase separation (Fig. 10b). Spherical PVP domains were dispersed in the PAN continuous phase, indicating the high interfacial tension between manganese/PVP and PAN. The phaseseparated polymer blend was electrospun from a single nozzle, which resulted in manganese ion/PVP-sheathed PAN nanofibers. The electrospun microphase-separated nanofibers were converted to manganese nanoclusters-decorated carbon nanofibers (Mn/ CNFs) via heat treatment. Fig. 10c shows the typical TEM images of the Mn/CNFs. The diameter (~50 nm) of the Mn/CNFs was smaller
than that observed for commonly electrospun CNFs (>100 nm), and manganese nanoclusters with diameters of ~15 nmwere dispersed well on the nanofibers. The PVP on the electrospun polymeric nanofibers is not a good carbon precursor, as mentioned earlier, which accounts for the reduced diameter of the resultant carbon nanofibers. Specifically, the metal precursor can alter the interfacial tension between the blended polymers, which led to the phase separation enabling the fabrication of new types of carbon nanofiber precursor via electrospinning.
In addition to metal/polymer coordination complexes, conducting polymers also belong to a class of versatile materials that allow the introduction of metal phases via a reversible redox mechanism. Conducting polymers can be reversibly doped and dedoped via oxidation and reduction reactions, respectively. Metalbased oxidizing agents allow the oxidation polymerization of the monomers, yielding metal atoms in the polymer. A postpolymerization treatment also enables the conducting polymers to be further oxidized and, at the same time, the metal-based oxidizing agents to be reduced to an atomic metal phase in the polymer. Several research examples can be given to aid an understanding of how metals can be effectively introduced into conducting polymers. First, silver-PPy core-shell nanoparticles have been obtained using a simple one-pot synthesis, in which silver nitrate was employed as a silver precursor as well as an initiator for the oxidative polymerization of the monomer [48]. When silver cations encounter the pyrrole monomers, they are converted into silver atoms after the oxidative coupling of the monomers. The
silver atoms are assembled into nanoseeds and the successive oxidative coupling of the monomers leads to the growth of PPy chains. As the silver nanoseeds are being formed, additional silver cations are concentrated onto the nanoseed surface due to the common ion adsorption effect [83]. Consequently, the PPy chains further grow onto the nanoseeds and finally form a PPy shell. The silver-PPy nanoparticles can be converted into silver-carbon nanoparticles because PPy is a good carbon precursor, as mentioned previously. In addition, just immersing the as-prepared PPy nanotubes into a silver nitrate solution also results in the decoration of their surface with silver nanoparticles [84], while the silver cations are reduced to silver atoms by PPy and the nitrate anions are doped onto PPy. Similarly, when electrospun poly(3,4ethylenedioxythiophene) (PEDOT) nanofibers were treated with KMnO4, a strong oxidizing agent, the oxidation level of PEDOT, which is indicative of its conductivity, further increased and in turn, MnO2 nanoclusters were created on the nanofibers [85]. Various noble metal nanoparticles consisting of palladium, platinum, rhodium, or ruthenium have also been decorated onto the PPy nanotubes at contents of 15e20wt% using the same postpolymerization treatment [86]. The noble metal-decorated PPy nanotubes were converted into their carbonized analogues at temperatures up to 830 C, in which most of the noble metal nanoparticles tend to be aggregated at temperatures >500 C. It should be noted that the characteristics of the as-formed metal phase can be altered during the carbonization process, while conducting polymers such as PEDOT and PPy serve as good carbon
precursors. In the case of the metal/polymer coordination complex, the metal precursor is thermally reduced to the metal phase during the carbonization process used for the polymer precursor. On the other hand, the conducting polymer or its monomer may act as a reducing agent for the metal precursor, allowing the chemical reduction of the metal precursor to occur prior to carbonization. In some cases, as explained earlier in Fig. 4, conducting polymers can entrap any residual metal precursor compounds when polymerized using the metal-based oxidizing agents. The entrapped metal precursors undergo carbonization in order to be reduced, which is similar to metal/polymer coordination complexes.

sections.heading: 3.3. Nanocarbon/polymer ensembles
sections.text:
As mentioned earlier, polymers are inherently unstable on the nanometer scale when compared tometals and ceramics. However, nanocarbon species have poor processability, which retards their practical applications. To overcome these problems, polymers can be coupled with nanocarbon species to make them processable and introduce excellent dimensional stability [87,88]. Representatively, well-defined nanocarbon species such as one-dimensional carbon nanotubes and two-dimensional graphene can act as a type of support to improve the dimensional stability of polymers on the nanoscale. As another approach, the nanocarbon species can be
integrated into polymer precursors, in which they can act as nanoseeds to alter the characteristics of the precursors. The microstructural and thermal properties of the nanocarbon species can play a vital role in eliciting unprecedented, fascinating properties from the polymer/nanocarbon hybrids themselves as well as their post-carbonization products.

sections.heading: 3.3.1. Nanocarbon supports
sections.text:
Graphite is composed of stacked graphene layers, held by van der Waals interactions between the layers. Much effort has been devoted to the intercalation of small molecules into graphite to achieve new, interesting properties from the resulting so-called graphite intercalation compounds [90e94]. Similarly, the polymer precursors can be also intercalated into the stacked graphene layers. Graphene is inherently hydrophobic and has an affinity to aromatic compounds in terms of its chemical structure. Most polymers are hydrophobic, many of which have aromatic moieties. Therefore, the hydrophobicity and aromaticity of a polymer may facilitate its intercalation into the stacked graphene layers especially in a non-hydrophobic medium [95]. A recent example of intercalating soluble-PANI chains into graphite promotes an understanding of how graphene acts as a support to strengthen the dimensional stability of a polymer [89]. While ordinary PANI is usually insoluble in common solvents, soluble-PANI is dissolved in some solvents with the aid of functional doping agents such as
dodecylbenezesulfonic acid and camphorsulfonic acid. SolublePANI was dissolved in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) and the sonication of graphite flakes in the PANI/NMP solution allowed the solubilized PANI chains to easily penetrate into the graphite layers (Fig. 11a). Finally, exfoliated graphene sheets stabilized by the soluble-PANI chains in the NMP continuous phase were produced (Fig. 11b). The exfoliated graphene sheets will be restacked into graphite if the PANI chains were not intercalated between them. Likewise, the PANI chains will be coagulated into larger polymer particles if they were not adsorbed onto the graphene surface. Random-alternating layered graphene/PANI nanoarchitecture films were obtained via vacuum-filtration of the PANI/graphene sheet solution through a porousmembrane. With the unique geometrical characteristics of the nanoarchitecture, the PANI chains confined into graphene sheets caused interesting properties leading to practical electrical and electrochemical applications [96,97]. The solvent medium is one of the important factors affecting the intercalation of the polymer as well as the status of the intercalated polymer. The interfacial energies between graphene and the PANIcontaining solvents were calculated using contact angle measurements. The interfacial energies were 7.9 and 30.6mNm 1 for the NMP only and NMP/water mixture, respectively. The low interfacial energy observed in NMP may be favorable for the intercalation of PANI chains into the small gaps between the graphene layers. The affinity of graphene to PANI will be reduced in the presence of water and, as a result, it was found that a conformational change occurred from linear to granular between the graphene sheets. This approach has been extended to other two-dimensional nanomaterials such as molybdenum disulfide [98], molybdenum selenium [99], and titanium carbide MXene [100], etc.
Polymer nanoparticles, not just solubilized polymer chains, can be also intercalated between graphene sheet supports, which prevents the coagulation of the nanoparticles by destabilization mechanisms such as the Ostwald ripening effect. For example, the intercalation of PPy nanospheres into graphite has been successfully explored in an aqueous phase, as shown in Fig. 12a. To effectively penetrate the 60 nm and 100 nm diameter nanospheres
between graphene sheets, the graphitewas preliminarily exfoliated using small molecule intercalants. Subsequently, sonicating graphite with PPy nanospheres in an aqueous solution leads to alternately stacked graphene-particulate PPy (GPPy) nanohybrids. The hydrophobic interactions formed between the PPy nanospheres and graphene in an aqueousmedium are considered to be a major driving force toward facilitating the intercalation of the nanoparticles with diameters of a few tens of nanometers. The PPy nanospheres were integrated into graphene sheets at different PPyto-graphite weight (Pw/Gw) ratios in the range of 2:1e10:1; the surface coverage of the nanospheres on graphene was proportional to the Pw/Gw ratio. Thermal treatment of the nanohybrids was carried out varying the PPy content and carbonization temperature [101]. As mentioned earlier, since PPy is a good carbon precursor, the GPPy nanohybrids were readily converted into carbonized products in the temperature range of 500e1000 C. Except for the reduced diameter of the nanospheres (~27% decrease at 1000 C observed for the 60 nm diameter nanospheres), as shown in Fig. 12b and d, the unique morphology of the nanohybrids was mostly well preserved even after the heat treatment step. The nitrogen atoms in the PPy repeating unit were traced (Fig. 12c), informing the qualitative characteristics of the resultant carbonized products. It is also well known that the crystallinity of sp2-hybridized carbon is proportional to the temperature used in the heat treatment step.
The Yamauchi group [102] fabricated a two-dimensional hierarchical hybrid architecture, referred to as a monomicelle@melamine-formaldehyde resin-coated graphene oxide sandwich-like structure, by assembling poly(styrene-b-2vinylpyridine-b-ethyelene oxide) triblock copolymer micelles onto the surface of graphene oxide sheets. Iron species (FeCl3) were further impregnated into the hierarchical hybrid architecture and a subsequent heat treatment step resulted in the two-dimensional graphene sandwich-structured composites patterned with sub-40 nm hollow iron and nitrogen-doped carbon nanospheres. Similarly, porous carbon/graphene nanocomposites [103] were derived from graphite oxide and polyvinylidene fluoride with a high
e (GPMNs) via direct physical exfoliation of graphite with PANI-glue (soluble-PANI). (b) bsence (left) and presence (right) of PANI-glue. The GPMNs show outstanding colloidal N-N and GPMN-W, respectively. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [89]. Copyright
specific surface area of 896e2724m2 g 1 and pore volume of 0.48e2.05 cm3 g 1, respectively. The introduction of threedimensional carbon nanostructures into two-dimensional graphene led to an enlarged surface area and enhanced porosity.
Numerous works have focused on growing different polymer nanostructures on graphene sheets such as nanorods [104] and nanorod arrays [70]. In these nanohybrid structures, it is obvious that rationally adjusting the key parameters such as the amount of
the polymer precursors, hybridization method, and carbonization temperature can lead to the selective production of qualitatively different carbon products. These results indicate a promising approach to the fabrication of porous carbon materials from polymer and nanocarbon supports for practical applications.

sections.heading: 3.3.2. Nanocarbon seeds
sections.text:
Nanocarbon species can be introduced as nanoseeds into the
bulk polymer phase prior to carbonization. It is clear that the small dimensions and surface characteristics of the nanoseeds significantly affect the crystallization of the polymer precursors. Furthermore, the high thermal conductivity of the nanocarbon species may induce unconventional thermal behavior in the polymer precursors during the carbonization process. In a related study, SWNTs have been incorporated into PVA/PAN binary blend precursors and the effect of the SWNTs as nanoseeds on the physical gelation of the blends was investigated, as shown in Fig. 13 [105]. The SWNTs-containing PVA/PAN blends gelled physically with appropriate amounts of water in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) (Fig. 13a). The physical gelation is determined by the phase behavior of the polymers in the water/DMSO mixture. Specifically, DMSO, a polar aprotic solvent, can dissolve both PVA and PAN, and it is also miscible with water. PVA has a better chemical affinity toward water when compared with PAN. Water forms hydrogen bonds with PVA and DMSO. Thus, when water was added to the SWNTs/PVA/PAN DMSO solution, the intermolecular interactions between PVA/PAN and PVA/DMSOweakened due to the PVA/water and DMSO/water interactions. When DMSO and water are mixed together, they can behave like co-non-solvents for the polymers because the DMSO/water (solvent/solvent) interaction is much larger than the polymer/solvent interactions. The co-non-solvents finally generate macropores in the physically cross-linked gels. Prior to PVA/PAN blending, the SWNTs were wrapped with PVA [106,107]. Importantly, the wrapping of SWNTs with PVA extends the binary polymer system to a ternary polymer system consisting of PVA bound to SWNTs, free PVA, and PAN. When compared with unbound, free PVA, PVA bound to SWNTs displays a distinct chain
Fig. 13. (a) The formation of gels depending on the water content (water/DMSO volume rati microstructure of the gels comprised of SWNTs, PVA, PAN, and water. (iv) Photographs of th obtained via freeze-drying). (b) Optical images of the SWNTs/PVA/PAN blends in DMSO, (i samples: (i) SbPG-4,0, (ii) SbPG-18,0, (iii) SbPG-4,7, (iv) SbPG-18,7, (v) SbPG-4,13, and (vi) Sb (c) SEM images of the SbCGs prepared using different amounts of the SWNTs and water: (i) samples were labeled SbCG-s,w, where s and w denote the amounts of SWNTs and water use Copyright 2018, Elsevier B.V. (A colour version of this figure can be viewed online.)
conformation andmobility of the polymer chains in the presence of water. When water is mixed with DMSO, they can act as co-nonsolvents via strong solvent/solvent interaction. Fig. 13b exhibits the effect of water addition on the phase behavior of the SWNTs/ PVA/PAN ensembles in DMSO solution. In the absence of water, spherical SWNTs/PVA domains of higher contrast were dispersed in PAN, indicating the high interfacial tension formed between SWNTs/PVA and PAN. However, upon increasing the SWNTs and water contents, the phase behavior of the SWNTs/PVA/PAN ensembles completely change; higher SWNTs and water contents accelerate the rate of physical gelation. Hence, the amounts of SWNTs and water are key parameters governing the phase separation and crystallization of the polymers. These physically crosslinked SWNT-in-binary-polymer gels (SbPGs) were successfully converted into carbonized structures, SWNTs-in-carbon gels (SbCGs) with macroporosity (Fig. 13c). Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) indicated that the SWNTs strongly affect the cyclization of the PAN chains during the thermal stabilization stage. It was found that the excellent thermal conductivity (>1000Wm 1 K 1) of the SWNTs facilitates the cyclization reaction through more effective heat transfer in the polymer precursor.
Nitrogen-doped porous activated carbon monoliths have also been produced via the temperature-induced phase separation of a PAN and multi-walled CNTs (MWNTs) mixture [108]. The carbon monoliths exhibit a surface area of 613.8m2 g 1 and pore volume of 0.366 cm3 g 1. The incorporated MWNTs enhance the crushing resistance of the carbon monoliths, indicating that the MWNTs constructed three-dimensional networks, preventing drastic dimensional changes or cracks. In addition to the enhanced

mechanical properties, a synergistic effect between the conducive backboned-MWNTs and the PAN-derived nitrogen functionalities was observed for the carbon monoliths, which was useful for their electrochemical applications [108,109].
Since SWNTs have an extremely high aspect ratio, it is considerably hard to integrate them directly into polymer nanoparticles. Nevertheless, several effective strategies have been exploited to fabricate SWNTs/polymer nanoparticles. First, as explained in the previous paragraph, SWNTs can be wrapped with PVA chains and then mixed with PAN in DMSO. The resulting SWNTs/PVA/PAN DMSO solution shows excellent colloidal stability and thus, successfully electrospun to yield SWNTs-in-binary-polymer nanofibers (SbPNFs) (Fig. 14) [110]. The electrospun nanofibers were prepared using different SWNTs concentrations of 0.02, 0.04, and 0.06wt%, labeled as SbCNF-1, SbCNF-2, and SbCNF-3, respectively. The color of the electrospun products evolved from white to dark gray upon increasing the SWNTs content. No inhomogeneity in color was observed, implying the uniform dispersion of the SWNTs in the nanofibers on a molecular level. The SbPNFs were transformed into SWNTs-in-carbon nanofibers (SbCNFs) via heat treatment. Due to the aforementioned effect of the SWNTs on the phase behavior of the polymers and the carbonization mechanism, the use of SbPNFs as carbon precursors enables the main properties of the resulting SbCNFs to be tailored. The textural properties of the SbCNFs, as well as their electrical properties, appear to depend on the concentration of the incorporated SWNT and the weight ratio of PVA-to-PAN.
More importantly, the SbPNF precursor contains SWNTs aligned along the nanofiber axis, providing enhanced crystallinity in the polymer nanofiber precursors as well as the resultant carbonized products. Polarizing optical microscopy (POM) showed that the polymer nanofiber precursor exhibits nematic long-range ordering along the nanofiber axis (Fig. 14a). The SWNTs/PVA/PAN solution has featureless and low-contrast images under cross-polarized light and the electrospun nanofibers were not subject to any additional processing treatment to enhance their orientation and crystallinity, such as drawing or annealing. Therefore, it can be concluded that the SWNTs/PVA-in-PAN dispersions undergo an isotropic-to-nematic phase transition via a whipping process during the electrospinning process. In the absence of the SWNTs, relatively little birefringence was observed from the resultant PVA/ PAN nanofibers even after electrospinning (Fig. 14b). Lastly, the water-soluble PVA phase was easily removed from the SbPNF precursor, further providing an opportunity to develop increased meso- and macroporosity (Fig. 14c). By using a similar preparation approach, both SWNTs and graphene can be incorporated into the electrospun nanofibers [111]. One-dimensional SNWTs and twodimensional graphene sheets were combined in the confined interior space of the electrospun nanofibers, which leads to the enhanced ordering of SWNTs, graphene sheets, and polymer chains along the nanofiber axis. Thermal treatment of the SWNTs/ graphene-in-polymer nanofiber precursor resulted in carbon nanofibers with effective porosity and tunable electrochemical

properties. SWNTs can also be integrated into biomass, not just synthetic polymers. A recent research study developed an efficient route for the selective incorporation of SWNTs into pine cone biomass [112]. SWNTs were individually dispersed with the aid of sodium cholate in an aqueous solution and then a pine cone was immersed into the aqueous SWNTs solution. Pine cone is composed of three major parts, bract scales, ovuliferous scales, and cone axis (parts 1, 2, and 3 shown in Fig. 15a). When the cone absorbs water through the bract scales, the ovuliferous scales show a folding motion. By taking advantage of the inherent water absorptionmechanism of the cone, the SWNTs are able to permeate selectively into the cone. Along the pathway of water absorption, the SWNTs were mainly impregnated into the scales of the cone. The cell wall of the cone contains stiff cellulose microfibrils embedded in a swellable matrix consisting of hemicelluloses, pectin, structural proteins, and lignin. As a result, the SWNTs/conewas converted into carbonized products, as shown in Fig. 15b. SEM indicated that the three parts of the cone had similar bundle-type longitudinal macroporous structures. The SWNTs/cone can be further modified via potassium hydroxide (KOH) activation to fully exploit its properties as a carbon precursor. Consequently, four different carbonized samples were fabricated for comparison: pristine cone (PC), activated cone (AC), SWNTs/ cone (SC), and activated SWNTs/cone (ASC). The parts of the samples were labeled in accordance with the sample name, followed by the part number. The weight changes in the samples during the heat treatment step were monitored using TGA (Fig. 15c). The three parts (1, 2, and 3) of the cone revealed different weight changes over the temperature range studied. Specifically, when compared to the PCs, the other samples presented higher char yields. While SWNTs inclusion affected the char yield, the KOH activation step changed the profile of the TGA curve. The textural properties were also highly dependent on the SWNTs inclusion and KOH activation (Fig. 15d). When compared with PCs, the SCs revealed a reduced absorption capacity in the micro-/meso-pores, indicating that the SWNTs impregnated into the cone facilitate the formation of more compact structures during carbonization. KOH activation causes enhanced meso-/macro-porosity in all parts of the cone, which was probably due to the swelling of the cell walls of the cone by KOH. Lastly, cyclic voltammetry and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy indicated that the ASCs showed the best electrochemical activity due to the lowest charge transfer resistance even though the specific surface area of the ASCs was lower than the ACs. It is apparent that the SWNTs play a critical role in improving the conductivity of the carbonized samples. The incorporation of small amounts of the nanocarbon species into biomass-based carbon materials may not only enhance the performance of the resulting carbonized materials, but also improve the cost effectiveness of manufacturing these materials, besides the constructive use of renewable materials with highly sustainable development.

sections.heading: 4. Summary and outlook
sections.text:
A variety of efforts have been devoted to exploring versatile carbon materials and the development of their synthetic methodologies for practical applications. Conventional carbon materials may involve carbon black, activated carbon, and carbon fibers, the synthetic routes of which have been well established in their related industries. In conventional carbon studies, most have focused on exploiting carbon materials with appropriate mechanical properties for composite industries, to which significant attention is still being paid. Typically, PAN-based carbon fibers and their processing techniques have been continuously ameliorated for use in fiber reinforced polymer composites. The emergence of nanocarbon species has provided a good opportunity to extend the
application of carbon materials to a broader range of research areas such as electronics, optics, and biomedical science. These nanocarbon species have fascinating properties, such as nanoscale sizes and tunable band gap energies, together with the advantages of conventional carbon materials. On the other hand, due to their conductivity and chemical inertness, conventional carbonmaterials have also been utilized in energy conversion and storage systems. Recently, in terms of environmental protection and/or sustainable development, an increasing effort is beingmade toward developing alternative energy sources and thus, various attempts have been made to discover new, promising carbon-based materials for related applications. For these applications, the electrical and textural properties of the materials, rather than mechanical properties, are the most important factors determining the performance of the resulting devices or systems. From this point of view, various kinds of precursors can be explored as candidate materials although their mechanical properties or char yields are not comparable to those of the previously reported precursors. In particular, most nanostructured carbon materials do not show excellent mechanical properties. However, they can offer plenty of room for tuning the textural properties and chemical functionalities.
Continuous advances in polymer science and technology have motivated researchers to develop alternative materials to previously reported metals and ceramics. Similarly, extensive studies have been conducted to screen various polymers as excellent carbon precursors. In addition, the appearance of nanotechnology in the late 1990s reminded researchers of the importance of surface or interface phenomena. Consequently, polymer nanoparticles as carbon precursors have been prepared using several methods and their direct conversion to carbon counterparts has been investigated. By virtue of their chemical and structural diversity, polymer precursors can be rationally designed to achieve nanostructured carbons with controlled properties for specific applications, where, similar to other materials, it is also important to control key processing parameters. In addition, polymer precursors may be readily compatible with metallic and ceramic phases, which opens up the possibility of realizing multicomponent functional carbon nanohybrids. The advantages of polymer precursors in achieving nanostructured carbons can be summarized as follows:
1) Technologies for fabricatingwell-defined polymer nanoparticles can be directly extended to achieving well-defined carbon nanoparticles. 2) Many different kinds of polymers such as synthetic polymers, natural polymers, and biomasses (containing natural polymers) can be investigated as candidates for carbon precursors. 3) Combinations of different kinds of polymers, including nonprecursors (as a kind of sacrificial porogens), can lead to completely different carbon products. 4) Simple, but powerful modifications such as adding metal precursors and blending another polymer can minimize altering the present materials' processing conditions, lowering the barrier to industrialization.
For example, right now, nanostructured carbons from polymer precursors exemplified in this review may not compete with the high mechanical properties of existing PAN-based carbon fibers. However, continuous research efforts in terms of interface science/ technologies, as well as polymer chemistry/physics may allow researchers to gain an in-depth insight into the carbonization mechanism and finally to produce nanostructured carbonmaterials with highmechanical properties from polymer precursors. Namely, a desired set of physicochemical properties may be introduced into the resulting carbon nanomaterials through rational molecular design or functionalization of the polymer precursor, which may
lead to a wider range of applications. Polymer precursors still have unexplored potential and thus, extensive future research is expected toward the discovery of novel polymer precursors.

metadata.abstractText: There has been a continuous pursuit toward developing techniques used to prepare enhanced carbon nanomaterials over the last several decades. In particular, the demand for new and advanced carbon nanomaterials is related to the need to optimize their physicochemical characteristics for specific applications. In this regard, polymer precursors have great potential for fabricating nanostructured carbons with desirable properties since the chemical structure and surface/interface properties of the polymer can be designed and tailored during the preparation process. Various types of polymers including synthetic polymers, natural polymers, and biomass have been investigated as carbon precursors. Elaborate efforts have been made to prepare polymer nanoparticles, polymer blends, and nanocarbon/polymer hybrids for versatile carbon nanomaterials via heat treatment processes, for which knowledge and technologies regarding the interface and polymer chemistry/physics are required. In addition, more indepth studies into the carbonization mechanism may lead to various strategies for creating advanced carbon nanomaterials with desirable properties. © 2019 Elsevier Ltd.
